title: An improved protocol for generation and characterization of human-induced pluripotent stem cell-derived retinal pigment epithelium cells

Pre-warm the mTeSR plus, CTS™ DPBS (1×) (-Ca2+/-Mg2+) to 37°C.
Note: One 6-well plate (at 80% confluency, about 1 million cells per well) is sufficient to initiate the RPE differentiation through EB formation (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]A inset).

The cells from 6 wells will be going into 6 wells of ultra-low attachment plates (in order to avoid any form of attachment) for the formation of EBs.
Prepare ultra-low attachment plates by adding 1 mL of mTeSR plus medium to each well.

Aspirate the spent medium from the plate containing iPSCs, and rinse the plate once with CTS™ DPBS (1×) (-Ca2+/-Mg2+) (Refer Table 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#tbl1] for volume).
table:files/protocols_protocol_2123_1.csv
Aspirate CTS™ DPBS (1×) (-Ca2+/-Mg2+) and add ReLeSR Solution to the plate containing iPSCs. Adjust the volume of ReLeSR Solution for various plate sizes (Refer Table 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#tbl1] for volume).
Add 1 mL/well of ReLeSR™ and aspirate ReLeSR™ within 1 min, such that colonies are exposed to a thin film of liquid.
Incubate at 37°C for 4 min ± 30 s.
Add an appropriate amount of mTeSR plus to each plate (Refer Table 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#tbl1] for volume) to stop the dissociation reaction.
Gently pipet the dissociated cells up and down sufficiently to disperse the colonies into a single-cell suspension.
Make sure to pipet gently to minimize the formation of bubbles.
Transfer the iPSC suspension from each well into a separate 15 mL tube and centrifuge the tube(s) at 200 g for 3 min to pellet the cells.
Carefully aspirate the supernatant(s) from the iPSC pellet(s).
Resuspend the pellet(s) with an appropriate amount (approximately 6 mL) of mTeSR plus medium.
Add resuspended cells to each 6 well ultra-low attachment plate containing 6 mL mTeSR plus medium (1 mL/well) with 10 μM ROCK inhibitor.
This day is considered Day 0. Incubate the cells for 24 h in a 37°C, 5% CO2 incubator to allow them to form EBs. Replace media with 2 mL of fresh mTeSR plus to remove Y-27632.
Day 1 and Day 2: Gently swirl the EB plate and bring the EBs to centre of the dish. Remove 1 mL of medium from well corner and add 1 mL of fresh mTeSR plus medium (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]A).
Differentiation induction and plating of EBs.
Prepare DIM as per Table 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#tbl2].

Note: Reconstitute and store growth factors as per manufacturer’s instructions.

Gradually shift the medium of the suspension cultures with EBs from mTeSR plus to differentiation induction media (DIM).
Day 3: Replace one part of mTeSR plus media with DIM (3:1) (Example: For 1 mL media, 750 μL mTeSR plus media, and 250 μL DIM).
Day 4: Replace one part of mTeSR plus media with DIM (1:1) (Example: For 1 mL media, 500 μL mTeSR plus media, and 500 μL DIM).
Day 5: Give complete media change (100%) with DIM.
Day 6: Matrigel coating and EB plating. Troubleshooting 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#troubleshooting]. Plate the EBs on matrigel coated culture dishes. At this point, EBs will be dense, spherical, and will have a defined boundary and will easily pool to the center when the plate is swirled.
Gently swirl the EB plate and transfer EBs from 3 wells of a 6 well plate into a 15 mL tube.
Allow the EBs to settle to the bottom of the tube at room temperature (20°C–25°C) inside the bio-safety cabinet (it will take about 3 min). Do not centrifuge the EBs.Remove supernatant (retain 1 mL of media), add 2 mL of DIM and then add 500 μL of resuspended media in a drop-wise manner using 1 mL pipette tip such that the EBs are distributed uniformly across the plate.
Gently shake the culture plate to aid the uniform distribution of the aggregates and carefully place it back in the incubator. Do not disturb for 24 h.

Note: We used AggreWell™800 Microwell Culture Plates (Stem Cell Technologies) for EB formation for the same RPE differentiation protocol. We did observe uniformity in terms of size of EBs generated using the multi-well plates. However, we did not find significant advantage with respect to final RPE numbers, processing time or cost incurred. Therefore, we continued using ultra low attachment dish to form EBs.
Day 7–8:
After 24 h, observe the plates for EB attachment. The majority of the EB’s will attach and start exhibiting outgrowth from the periphery.
Note: Floating EB’s can be discarded at this point while changing medium.
Do complete media change with 100% DIM (Refer Table 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#tbl1] for volume).
Introducing Differentiation Propagation Media (DPM).
Prepare DPM as shown in Table 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#tbl3].
table:files/protocols_protocol_2123_3.csv
Note: Add N1 supplement to filtered media.
Media can be stored at 4°C for 2 weeks.
Day 9: Gradually shift the medium from DIM to differentiation propagation media (DPM). Replace one part of DIM media with DPM (1:1) (Example: For 1 mL media, 500 μL DIM and 500 μL DPM).
Day 10: Give complete media change (100%) with DPM.
Day 11–22: Feed cultures with DPM on alternate days until day 22 (Refer Table 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#tbl1] for volume) (Figures 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]B and 1C).
Introducing Retinal Pigment Epithelium Maturation Media (RPEMM).
Prepare RPEMM as shown in Table 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#tbl4].

Note: Add growth factors & supplement to filtered media. Reconstitute and store growth factors as per manufacturer’s instructions.
https://www.sigmaaldrich.com/IN/en/product/sigma/t0625[href=https://www.sigmaaldrich.com/IN/en/product/sigma/t0625]. https://www.sigmaaldrich.com/IN/en/product/sigma/h6909[href=https://www.sigmaaldrich.com/IN/en/product/sigma/h6909]. https://www.sigmaaldrich.com/IN/en/product/sigma/t5516[href=https://www.sigmaaldrich.com/IN/en/product/sigma/t5516]. Media can be stored at 4°C for 2 weeks.
Gradually switch the medium from DPM to Retinal Pigment Epithelium Maturation Media (RPEMM).
Day 23: Replace one part of DPM media with RPEMM (1:1) (Example: For 1 mL media, 500 μL DIM and 500 μL RPEMM).
Day 24: On day 24 switch to complete RPEMM (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]D).

Day 25–45: Feed the cultures with RPEMM on alternate days until day 40 (refer Table 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#tbl1] for volume).
Day 40 (±5): Enrichment step by passaging of RPE. RPE cells can be passaged between day 35 to day 45 after the onset of pigmentation and this step helps in enriching the pigmenting cells (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]E). Troubleshooting 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#troubleshooting].
Matrigel coating-prepare matrigel coated plates as previously stated (Refer step 4 under preparations).
For 1 × 6 well plate, aliquot 3 mL of gentle cell dissociation reagent (GCDR) and 3 mL StemPro Accutase in a 15 mL tube and pre-warm in incubator at 37°C for 30 min.
Aspirate the culture medium and gently wash once with CTS™ DPBS (1×) (-Ca2+/-Mg2+) 1 mL/well.
Incubate the cells with 1:1 ratio of pre-warmed GCDR and Accutase at 37°C for 11–12 min.
Note: If required incubate for an additional 2 min at step 4 to ensure complete dissociation into single cells.
Pipette gently to dissociate into single cells or aggregates of 5–10 cells and dilute with RPEMM media.
Collect cell suspension in a 15 mL tube and centrifuge at 200 g for 3 min. Remove supernatant.
Aspirate matrigel just before seeding cells and add RPEMM media in each well (Refer Table 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#tbl1] for volume).
Resuspend cell pellet in RPEMM and seed cells 1:2 or 1:3 in matrigel coated plates.
Allow cells to attach without disturbing for 24–48 h.
After proper attachment of cells, resume media change.
Day 47–75 or later.
Feed the cultures with RPEMM on alternate days until day 75–80.
OPTIONAL STEP: Day 60 (±5): Passaging RPE.

RPE cells could be passaged again around day 60 (±5) by following the steps mentioned in Enrichment step by passaging of RPE (Refer step 5 in step-by-step method details[href=https://www.wicell.org#step-by-step-method-details]) and maintain upto day 90–100 by changing medium on alternate days. This step can be implemented for further scale-up if there is a need to generate larger numbers of RPE cells for pre-clinical safety and toxiciological studies.
Day 75 or later: Selection and cryopreservation. RPE cells show cuboidal morphology at day 75 with visible deposits of melanin pigment (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]F). Cultures are frozen using commercially available cryoprotectant - CryoStor® CS10 Freeze Media - BioLife Solutions in 1.8 mL NUNC cryotubes.
Wash the cells twice with CTS™ DPBS (1×) (-Ca2+/-Mg2+).
Add pre-warmed GCDR and Accutase at 1:1 ratio and incubate for 10–12 min at 37°C.
Note: If enrichment step by passaging the RPE cells is not performed at day 40/45 then follow step c, else directly move to step d.
Manually remove the visibly non-pigmented cluster areas if any (non-black) using 20–200 μL pipette tips and discard them. Gently flush the pigmenting patches out from the wells using 1 mL pipette tips.
Note: Repeat the flushing carefully in presence of RPEMM until all the visibly pigmented patches have been successfully detached.
Collect the cells and mix with equal volumes of RPEMM. Centrifuge at 200 g for 2 min at room temperature (20°C–25°C).
Critical: After counting the cells, determine the number of cryovials required to freeze approximately 1 million cells per vial in 1 mL of cold freezing medium. Label accordingly with cell line name, cell type, initials and date on each cryovial.
To the RPE cell pellet add Cryostor CS10 freezing medium and gently mix the RPE cell suspension.
Cryopreserve the cells (in suspension) in cryovials at 1 million cells per vial.

Place the cryovials in Mr. Frosty freezing container and store at −80°C for 24 h.
After 24 h, transfer the cells to the liquid nitrogen storage tank and update cryotank binder.
Characterization of RPE in vitro.
Protein expression by Immunocytochemistry. Immunocytochemistry of differentiation cultures help visualize the expression level and localization of stage-specific retinal markers and authenticates successful differentiation of iPSC to RPE (Figures 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]A–2E; Table 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#tbl5]).

Images showing the expression of RPE commitment marker MITF (A), melanocyte protein- PMEL17 (B), RPE maturation markers TYRP1, RPE65 and TYR (C-E)and tight junction marker ZO-1 (D and E).

Day 1.
Aspirate the culture medium and gently wash thrice with CTS-DPBS (1×) (-Ca2+/-Mg2+) with fixing solution and incubate for 15–20 min at room temperature (20°C–25°C).
Remove fixing solution and gently wash thrice with CTS-DPBS (1×) (-Ca2+/-Mg2+).
Permeabilize and block by adding blocking solution for 30 min at room temperature (20°C–25°C).
Gently wash thrice with CTS-DPBS (1×) (-Ca2+/-Mg2+).
Add primary antibody diluted in antibody diluent and incubate overnight (16–20 h) at 4°C. Day 2.
Remove primary antibody and wash thrice with CTS-DPBS (1×) (-Ca2+/-Mg2+).

Add secondary antibody diluted in antibody diluent and incubate in dark for 60 min at room temperature (20°C–25°C).
Remove secondary antibody solution and wash thrice with CTS-DPBS (1×) (-Ca2+/-Mg2+).
Counterstain with 1 μg/mL concentration of DAPI and incubate in dark for 10 min at room temperature (20°C–25°C).
Remove DAPI solution and wash once with CTS-DPBS (1×) (-Ca2+/-Mg2+).
Add CTS-DPBS (1×) (-Ca2+/-Mg2+) (300 μL for 1 well of a 4 well plate) and visualize under a fluorescent microscope.
Pause point: Fixed cells from step (ii) can be stored in CTS-DPBS (1×) (-Ca2+/-Mg2+) at 4°C for 1 week before proceeding to staining.
Immunophenotyping by Flow cytometry. Flow cytometry analysis of RPE cells helps to quantify the levels of protein expression providing reconfirmation of successful differentiation of iPSC to RPE (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]F). Enzymatic dissociation of RPE into single cells.
Aspirate culture media and wash cells with CTS-DPBS (1×) (-Ca2+/-Mg2+).
Harvest cells enzymatically (GCDR and Accutase at 1:1 ratio for 10–12 min; (Refer Section 7, steps a-d under step-by-step method details[href=https://www.wicell.org#step-by-step-method-details]) and gently pipet to make a single cell suspension.
Centrifuge at 200 g for 3 min and discard the supernatant.
Wash the pellet by resuspending in CTS-DPBS (1×) (-Ca2+/-Mg2+) and centrifuge at 200 g for 3 min.
Fix the cells by adding 1 mL of 4% PFA for 10 min at room temperature (20°C–25°C).
Wash the cells with CTS-DPBS (1×) (-Ca2+/-Mg2+) and centrifuge at 200 g for 3 min and completely remove CTS-DPBS (1×) (-Ca2+/-Mg2+).
Add 1 mL of ice-cold methanol to the pellet and incubate at 4°C for 20 min.
Wash cells with FACS buffer (Refer Table 6[href=https://www.wicell.org#tbl6]) and centrifuge at 200 g for 3 min.
table:files/protocols_protocol_2123_6.csv
Stain the cells with primary antibody at an optimized concentration in 100 μL FACS buffer and incubate for 30 min at room temperature (20°C–25°C).

Repeat wash with FACS buffer and centrifuge at 200 g for 3 min.
Add secondary antibody in 100 μL FACS buffer to the pellet at optimized concentration and incubate in dark for 30 min.
Vortex the vials every 10 min to ensure mixing.
Wash with CTS-DPBS (1×) (-Ca2+/-Mg2+) and resuspend in FACS buffer.
Transfer the cells to flow tubes for flow cytometry analysis.
Pause point: Fixed cells from step (vi) can be stored in CTS-DPBS (1×) (-Ca2+/-Mg2+) at 4°C for 48–72 h before proceeding to permeabilization and blocking.
Note: Permeabilization, blocking, and immunolabelling are done simultaneously to avoid cell loss during washing steps.
Gene expression analysis by quantitative real-time PCR. Gene expression profiling helps to understand the molecular signature of these de novo generated RPE cells in comparison to undifferentiated iPSC. Purification of total RNA. Pellet preparation:
Collect the cells in a sterile 1.5 mL tube (Refer Section 7, steps a-d under step-by-step method details[href=https://www.wicell.org#step-by-step-method-details]) and centrifuge for one min at 200 g to pellet down the cells.
Remove the supernatant carefully and snap freeze the pellet using liquid nitrogen. Store the snap-frozen cells at −80°C until RNA isolation. RNA isolation:
For RNA isolation, use the RNeasy Mini kit (Qiagen) and perform all the steps at room temperature (20°C–25°C).
Add 500 μL RLT buffer to the Cell pellet and add equal volume of 70% ethanol. Add the mixure into the spin column and spin at 8,000 g for 1 min.
Wash the column once with buffer RW1 and twice with buffer RPE. Perform all the washing steps at 8,000 g for 1 min.
For the final elution, add 20 μL of RNAse free water directly to the spin column, incubate for a minute, and spin at 8,000 g for 1 min to elute the RNA.

Keep the RNA immediately on ice and quantify using a nanodrop. cDNA synthesis:
cDNA transcription is carried out using a Verso cDNA synthesis kit.
Critical: Perform all the reaction setup steps on ice.
Verso cDNA kit protocol recommends template RNA concentrations ranging from 1 pg to 1 μg. Prepare the cDNA synthesis reaction mix on ice by using the volumes mentioned in Table 7[href=https://www.wicell.org#tbl7].
table:files/protocols_protocol_2123_7.csv
Incubate at 42°C for 45 min for cDNA synthesis to occur and 95°C for 2 min for enzyme inactivation. The synthesized cDNA can be used for qPCR analyses.
Note: RT enhancer used from the kit degrades dsDNA during the transcription of RNA and it gets inactivated at 95°C in the second step. This eliminates the need for DNase treatment.
RT- qPCR. Analyzing the expression of various genes by RT-qPCR. RT-qPCRs were done using QuantStudio3 Real-Time PCR machine and the results were analyzed using the 2-ddCt method. Perform RT-qPCR experiment preferably with minimal light.
qPCR using SYBR green : Prepare 20 μL reaction mixture containing 10 μL of SYBR green mix (2×), 1 μL each of forward and reverse primer (stock 10 μM), 2 μL of cDNA (50 ng), and 6 μL of water (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]G).
Run the qPCR reaction as mentioned in Table 8[href=https://www.wicell.org#tbl8].
table:files/protocols_protocol_2123_8.csv
qPCR using Taqman probes: Prepare a 20 μL reaction mixture containing 10 μL of Taqman master mix (2×), 1 μL of the gene-specific probe (stock 20×), 2 μL of cDNA (50 ng), and 7 μL of water (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]H).
Run the qPCR reaction as mentioned in Table 9[href=https://www.wicell.org#tbl9].
table:files/protocols_protocol_2123_9.csv
Quantification of the gene expression: Here, the expression of test genes is normalized against the expression level of Beta-ACTIN/GAPDH as housekeeping genes. Calculate the fold change is by normalizing the expression of the samples (RPE) against a control (iPSC).

Measurement of extracellular secretion of protein by Enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA). Secretion of Pigment-Epithelium Derived growth Factor (PEDF) is an important criterion to assess the polarity of in vitro generated RPE (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]I). Quantification of PEDF is done enzymatically using a commercially available kit (Human Serpin F1/ PEDF Duoset ELISA kit).
Coat the ELISA plate with 100 μL of capture antibody and incubate overnight at room temperature (20°C–25°C).
Wash the coated wells with wash buffer 3 times. Perform all the steps at room temperature (20°C–25°C).
Add 300 μL of reagent diluent as a blocking solution and incubate for 1 h. Repeat washing 3 times with wash buffer.
Add 100 μL of the sample (the day on which the cell supernatant is harvested) and standards diluted in reagent dilution to the coated wells and incubate for 2 h. Carefully wash thrice with wash buffer.
Add 100 μL of detection antibody diluted in reagent diluent and incubate for 2 min.
Carefully wash thrice with wash buffer.
Add 100 μL of Streptavidin-HRP to each well. Cover the plate and incubate for 20 min in dark.
Carefully wash thrice with wash buffer.
Add 100 μL of substrate solution and incubate for 20 min. Avoid exposing the plates to direct light.
Add 50 μL of Stop Solution to each well and mix the plate gently.
Determine the optical density of each well immediately at 450 nm and 540 nm for background subtraction using Varioskan LUX microplate reader.
The concentration of PEDF from the samples is analyzed by plotting the standard values as a graph.
Precilical safety and efficacy studies in animal model. Sub-retinal transplantation of freeze-thawed RPE cells in animal model (rat) helps to evaluate the efficacy and safety of these cells in vivo, thereby providing important IND enabling pre-clinical data.
Animal maintenance.

Breed a colony of Pigmented RCS (RCS-p+/Lav) rats (NIH Rat Resource and Research Center, #315).
Feed animals a standard laboratory chow and maintain animals on a 12 h dark/light cycle.
Wean animals at postnatal day (PD) 21 and administer oral cyclosporine A (210 mg/L; Gengraf, North Chicago, IL) in drinking water. Animals should be kept on cyclosporine A until sacrifice.
Cell preparation. Preparing the cells prior to injection under aspectic conditions following this protocol is extremely important for best performace of the cells post transplantation into animals.
Remove cells from liquid nitrogen storage and thaw in a 37°C water bath for 2 min.
Add 1 mL of pre-warmed DMEM/F12 media dropwise to the vial.
Transfer cells to a 15 mL tube containing 5 mL of pre-warmed DMEM/F12 media.
Rinse cryotube with 1 mL of DMEM/F12 media and add to 15 mL tube.
Centrifuge cells at 150 g for 5 min at room temperature (20°C–25°C).
Aspirate supernatant and re-suspend cells in 1 mL of pre-warmed DMEM/F12 media.
Carefully pipette up and down to re-suspend the cells.
Remove 10 μL of cell suspension and add to 10 μL of 0.08% Trypan blue solution.
Pipette up and down and load hemacytometer (10 μL each side).
Count viable cells.
Centrifuge cell suspension again at 150 g for 5 min.
Resuspend cells in appropriate volume to achieve desired concentration for injection.
Subretinal injections (Wilson et al., 2017[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib5]). We tested cryopreserved RPE frozen at day 75–80 for subretinal injections and we strongly believe that at this stage iPS-RPE are suitable for application in transplantation studies. Transplantation of cells at earlier stages of differentiation is possible but progenitor cell behavior is not well known in vivo.
One hour before injections, dilate pupils with 1% tropicamide and 2.5% phenylephrine.
Anesthetize eyes with topical 0.5% proparacaine HCl.

Sedate animals with intraperitoneal ketamine/xylazine (100/10 mg/kg).
Cut the corner of the eyelid to allow for visualization of the posterior retina. Use a hemostat to reduce blood accumulation.
Make a small scleral/choroidal incision (∼1 mm) 2-mm posterior to the limbus in the dorsotemporal region using 27 gauge needle tip.
Make a small lateral corneal puncture using a 30-G needle to limit increases of intraocular pressure and reduce efflux of cells following injection.
Deliver two microliters of cell suspension containing the total cell dose or control media into the subretinal space using a fine glass pipette (internal diameter, 75–150 μm) inserted into the subretinal space. The glass pipette is connected to a 10 μL Hamilton syringe (Hamilton, Reno, NV) with small-bore (400 μL total volume) microtubing.
After delivery, using a glass coverslip, look at the retina under the microscope and score the subretinal bleb based on size and injection related issues, for example: bleeding, bubbles, cells in the vitreous.
Place 0.5% erythromycin ointment on eyes and let animals recover from anesthesia.
On surgery day, administer intraperitoneal dexamethasone (1.0 mg/kg). Administer dexamethasone to animals every other day for 2 weeks post-cell transplantation to minimize a potential inflammatory response.
Note: Injections should occur between PD22 and PD25. Animals need to be placed on cyclosporine A one day prior to injections.
Optokinetic Tracking (OKT). Optokinetic thresholds should be assessed using a virtual optomotor system (VOS; CerebralMechanics) comprising of four computer monitors arranged in a square, displays facing inwards. On the monitors, a virtual cylinder displays sine-wave gratings that can be rotated either clockwise or counter clockwise permitting evaluation of both the left and right eyes independently; the left eye responds to clockwise, and the right eye to counterclockwise movement (Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]C).

Place the animal on the pedestal in the center of the four computer monitors. Allow the animals 5 min to acclimate to the pedestal.
Using the Cerebral Mechanics software, set up the simple staircase examination for both eyes, keeping the contrast set to 100%.
The program will begin with a low spatial frequency, the cylinder will rotate and if the grating is resolved, the animal will respond with a reflexive head and neck movement tracking the grating. If the animal responds click ‘yes’, if the animal doesn’t respond click ‘no’. Based on this input, the spatial frequency of the grating will then incrementally increase until the animals no longer track the stimulus, resulting in a maximal spatial frequency threshold.
Once the exam is finished, take the animal off the pedestal and return them to their home cage.
Note: The RCS rat has a near normal OKT through PD60. To determine the functional rescue resulting from the cell transplantation, this exam is most optimal no earlier than PD90.
Fundus photography. A fundus camera or retinal camera is designed to observe the inner regions of eye, mainly the retina. Fundus images can be obtained at any time post-injection to verify successful transplantation of cells and the length of cell survival (Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]A).
Dilate pupils with 1% tropicamide and 2.5% phenylephrine.
Anesthetize eyes with topical 0.5% proparacaine HCl.
Sedate animals with intraperitoneal ketamine/xylazine (100/10 mg/kg).
Keep eyes lubricated with 2.5% Goniovisc Hypromellose.
Using the Micron IV (Phoenix-Micron, Inc.) imaging system use the white light to capture bright field images of the retina.
When imaging, use the optic nerve head as a guide, but then position the animal so that the peripheral/temporal region of the retina, where the injection took place, is in view.

Place 0.5% erythromycin ointment on eyes and let animals recover from anesthesia.
Tissue preparation. Tissue samples must be appropriately harvested and prepared for histology and immunohistochemistry studies. Sample preparation include processes such as fixation, dehydration, embedding and sectioning.
After euthanasia following IACUC guidelines, enucleate the eye as rapidly as possible.
Place the enucleated eye into cold 4% paraformaldehyde (PFA). Try to maintain a 10–20× fixative to tissue ratio.
After 10–60 min of fixation, remove the anterior chamber of the eye including the lens and replace the remaining eye cup into 4% PFA. Place samples in PFA on ice.
Place the eyes in 2°C–8°C for 24–48 h.
After 24–48 h, remove the PFA solution and add an equal volume of cold 10% sucrose solution in 1×PBS.
Place the eyes in 2°C–8°C for 24 h.
Remove the 10% sucrose solution and replace the solution with an equal volume of cold 20% sucrose solution.
Place the eyes in 2°C–8°C for 24 h.
Remove the 20% sucrose solution and replace the solution with an equal volume of cold 30% sucrose solution.
Place the eyes in 2°C–8°C for 24 h.
Remove the eye cup from the 30% sucrose solution and dab dry on a piece of filter paper.
Place the eye cup cut side down on filter paper to allow the vitreous to drain out of the eye cup. Repeat until the filter paper remains dry. See Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]A to view complete vitreous removal on filter paper (black represents vitreous imprint on the filter paper).

Figure 3. Tissue preparation for histopathology
(A–C) Diagramatic representation of vitreous removal on filter paper (A), orientation of eye cup (B) and freezing of cryomold (C) for histopathology.
Place the eye cup into a labeled cryomold and fill with OCT media.

Orient the eye cup toward the front of the cryomold and orient the injection site at about 2’oclock for OS (oculus sinister left) eyes and 10’oclock for OD (oculus dextrus right) eyes (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]B).
Freeze the cryomold, containing the eye, in a liquid nitrogen bath. Ensure that the liquid nitrogen does not directly touch the OCT media, but only contacts the walls of the cryomold (Figure 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig3]C). Direct contact of liquid nitrogen to OCT media creates air bubbles, ruining sample integrity.
Once the media no longer has a glossy shine, remove it from the liquid nitrogen bath.
Tightly wrap the cryomold in aluminum foil to try to limit the block’s exposure to air.
Place wrapped blocks in a −20°C freezer.
Histology / Immunohistochemistry. Hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) and immunohistochemical staining are valuable tools for detecting histopathological changes and specific antigens in tissues.
Section eye blocks at 12 μm.
Obtain approximately 40 slides containing 4 sections per slide from each eye.
Collect sections in a 5-slide series to provide a representative section every 60 μm on each slide throughout the eye-cup.
Stain the first slide of each series with cresyl violet or hematoxylin and eosin and examine retinal damage/toxicity and evidence of photoreceptor rescue (Figure 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]B).

Figure 4. RPE transplantation in RCS rats
(A and B) Fundus imaging (A) and H & E staining (B) of the saline and RPE injected (sub-retinal) eye of RCS rats. Inset (A) shows human nuclear antigen positive cells in cell injected eye at P90.
(C) Optokinetic tracking of saline and RPE transplanted animals showed improved visual acuity.
(D) Immunostaining of retinal sections with cone arrestin after transplantation.

(E and F) Quantification of retinal thickness (E) and number of cones (F) from low and high dose RPE transplanted animals between nasal and temporal regions of the retina. Scale bars 100 μm.
For immunohistochemistry, dry slides for at least 30 min after removing from freezer.
Block for 45 min with 4% horse serum, 1% bovine serum albumin (BSA), 0.5% triton x in phosphate buffered saline (PBS).
Add primary antibodies (anti-cone arrestin, generously provided by W. Clay Smith, PhD, University of Florida) to blocking buffer and incubate overnight (minimum 15 h) at 4°C.
The next day, wash 3 × 5 min with 1×PBS.
Add secondary antibodies (1:300) in blocking buffer and incubate for 45 min in the dark at room temperature (20°C–25°C).
Wash 3 × 5 min with 1×PBS.
Incubate with DAPI in the dark for 10 min.
Wash 2 × 5 min with 1×PBS.
Coverslip the slides with 100 μL of Fluoromount G.
Quantification of photoreceptors. The outer nuclear layer thickness (ONL) was measured with the help of immunohistochemical staining as the primary indicator of photoreceptor rescue (Figures 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig4]D–4F).
Use a scanning laser confocal microscope (Leica SP5 using LAS AF software; Leica) to image stained slides. Keep laser intensity settings (gain) consistent for each emission wavelength.
Collect Z-stack images at ×10 and ×20 magnification at 1024 × 1024-resolution with 1-μm step size.
Keep color channels separate as each color channel z-stack is flattened. Save each color channel image and the color merged image as TIFF files.
Count ONL cell bodies within the rows of the ONL in both temporal (injected) and nasal (non-injected) regions to obtain retinal thickness – nuclei values.
Count cone arrestin positive cells in both temporal (injected) and nasal (non-injected) regions to obtain cones per image values.

Have three observers blinded to the dosage and age group generate counts.
Using data collected in steps d-f , average ONL counts and photoreceptor counts per group and present data from both temporal (injected) and nasal (non-injected) regions.
